TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national who was born in DATE . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government were represented by PERSON , ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant arrived in GPE for the first time in DATE to visit his brother , who was studying in GPE . Having failed to demonstrate that his brother was able to provide economic guarantees for his subsistence and return travel , he was expelled from the country . DATE , on DATE , the applicant again entered GPE and applied for a residence permit in order to study in the country . On DATE his application was rejected by ORG ( GPE ) . Apparently , he thereafter remained in the country illegally . In DATE he again applied for a residence permit as a foreign student , submitting that he had been admitted to ORG . On DATE he was , on this basis , given a temporary residence permit , effective until DATE .

In DATE the applicant returned to GPE . After re - entering GPE in DATE he remained there without permission until he again returned to GPE sometime during the autumn of DATE . DATE he did his military service in GPE . He remained in GPE until DATE .

In DATE the applicant was granted an entry visa to GPE to visit his brother . In DATE he married a NORP citizen whom he had first met during his initial period of residence in GPE , and in DATE he was granted a DATE temporary residence permit based on this relationship . Shortly before the expiry of this permit he again returned to GPE in DATE and remained there , without his wife , until DATE . The applicant has submitted that he remained in GPE on account of family problems there and that he was in continuous contact with his wife through telephone calls . After coming back to GPE , where now also his parents and his CARDINAL brothers were living , he was granted a permanent residence permit in DATE .

In DATE and DATE , respectively , CARDINAL sons were born to the applicant and his wife . The sons are both NORP citizens . In DATE the couple divorced . DATE the applicant made several journeys to GPE , the longest of which lasted for DATE . At visits made to GPE in DATE and DATE he apparently told relatives that he was considering a permanent return to his native country .

In the course of the police investigation into the narcotics offences of which he was subsequently convicted , the applicant stated that before he came under suspicion he had in principle moved back to GPE . He had rented an apartment there for a year , and his intention was to go to GPE for CARDINAL periods every year and to remain for DATE each time . DATE he intended to spend in GPE in order to see his children . The applicant further stated that he had better job opportunities in GPE , as well as contacts with persons who could help him . He also had a higher standard of living in that country than in GPE . The applicant ’s views in this respect were confirmed at his trial , during which he stated , inter alia , that his intention was to move back to GPE .

During his different periods of residence in GPE the applicant has been convicted of several criminal offences . Thus , in DATE he was found guilty of , inter alia , making unlawful threats and was given a suspended sentence and ordered to pay a fine . In DATE he was convicted of driving without a driver ’s licence and engaging in unlawful commercial traffic and sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . In DATE he was convicted of robbery and of carrying knives in a public place and sentenced to imprisonment for DATE and DATE . He was released on probation in DATE .

On DATE ORG ( tingsrätten ) of ORG convicted the applicant and CARDINAL co - accused of aggravated narcotics offences involving the transportation from GPE and attempted importation into GPE of QUANTITY of heroin in DATE . The applicant was sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . Moreover , the court considered that the offences were of such a character that each of the accused should be expelled from GPE with life - long bans on their return .

In his appeal against that judgment , the applicant , in regard to the question of expulsion , relied on his links to NORP society and also submitted that there was a risk that he would be punished again in GPE for the narcotics offences of which he had already been convicted in GPE .
On DATE ORG ( PERSON hovrätt ) upheld ORG judgment in its entirety .

The applicant sought leave to appeal against the appellate court ’s judgment . He again referred to his strong links to NORP society , including his long period of residence in the country , his close relationship with his CARDINAL young children , and the fact that both his parents and his CARDINAL brothers were residing in the country . He also invoked a letter from his former wife , in which she stated , inter alia , that it would be impossible for her to finance any future visits to GPE and that the applicant ’s expulsion would therefore be tantamount to depriving the children of their father .
On DATE ORG ( ORG domstolen ) refused the applicant leave to appeal . He started to serve his prison sentence on DATE .
The applicant ’s children visited the applicant in prison for the first time in DATE . During his time in prison he met the children on a total of CARDINAL occasions .

During the applicant ’s time in prison , CARDINAL petitions have been made to the Government for a revocation of the expulsion order . They were rejected by decisions of QUANTITY DATE , DATE and DATE respectively .

In support of his first request , the applicant submitted that he had no significant link to GPE and that his expulsion to that country would cause detriment to his children who were unable to accompany him . He also noted that his youngest son was receiving therapy at a child psychiatric clinic for the problems he was experiencing as a consequence of the expulsion .

In support of his third request , made in DATE , the applicant added that , following his divorce in DATE , he had maintained a good relationship with his former wife and his children and had visited them several times a week , and that they regularly came to visit him in prison . The youngest son had experienced the greatest problems as a result of the applicant ’s absence and he was therefore regularly seeing a psychologist .

On DATE the applicant was released from prison on probation . By a decision of the GPE police authority he was placed in detention on the same day pursuant to chapter CARDINAL , sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ( Utlänningslagen , DATE ) , inter alia on the ground that there was reason to believe that he would otherwise abscond . On DATE ORG ( länsrätten ) in GPE upheld the detention order .

By a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG , at the request of the applicant and his former wife , ordered that they should have joint custody of their children . Previously , the former wife had had sole custody .
On DATE the order for the applicant ’s expulsion was enforced and the applicant deported to GPE .

In an opinion of DATE PERSON , a qualified psychologist and psychotherapist at the GPE education administration stated , inter alia , the following . At a meeting with the CARDINAL sons and their mother , the eldest son , who was aware of the applicant ’s deportation , had said that he was depressed and found the whole situation hopeless . The youngest son had not been informed of the deportation , as the family feared that he would not be able to bear the pain . He had refused to attend school and was generally unhappy and afraid . He stated that he would commit suicide if his father were to be expelled to GPE .

Pursuant to chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL of LAW ( ORG ) , a crime may , apart from ordinary sanctions , result in special consequences defined by law . Expulsion on account of a criminal offence constitutes such a special consequence .

Provisions on expulsion on this ground are laid down in LAW ( Utlänningslagen , CARDINAL ) . According to chapter DATE , section QUANTITY , an alien may not be expelled from GPE on account of having committed a criminal offence unless certain conditions are satisfied . Firstly , he must be convicted of a crime that is punishable by imprisonment . Secondly , he may only be expelled if he is in fact sentenced to a more severe punishment than a fine and if ( CARDINAL ) it may be assumed , on account of the nature of the crime and other circumstances , that he will continue his criminal activities in GPE or ( CARDINAL ) the offence , in view of the damage , danger or violation involved for private or public interests , is so serious that he ought not to be allowed to remain in the country .

Furthermore , under chapter CARDINAL , section QUANTITY , when considering whether or not an alien should be expelled , the court shall take into account his links to NORP society . In so doing , the court shall pay particular attention to the living conditions and family circumstances of the alien and the length of time he has resided in GPE . There must be a reasonable proportionality between the offence and the resulting consequences , and the stronger the links are between the alien and GPE the more serious the offence must be in order to justify his expulsion . Thus , an alien who has been a holder of a permanent residence permit for DATE when proceedings are initiated against him , or who at that time has been residing in GPE for DATE , may not be expelled unless there are exceptional reasons for his expulsion . As regards aliens who are considered to be refugees , special rules apply .
